Award.AwardTitle: Study of random walks in random environments, and random matrices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Random walks are arguably the stochastic processes most studied by mathematicians, having the widest range of applications in fields as diverse as the physical sciences, engineering, and the social sciences. Though the theory of random walks is by now well developed, this is not at all the case when one changes the medium in which the walk evolves to a random medium, thus obtaining a random walk in random environment (RWRE). Such RWRE's can be used to model many problems of motion in random media in the physical and engineering sciences, and are mathematically appealing because on the one hand the model is very simply stated, while on the other hand established tools for studying processes in random media are not applicable in the study of RWRE. The goal of the current proposal is to develop new basic probabilistic techniques that will allow one to make provable predictions concerning the behavior of RWRE. It is expected that such techniques will be useful in the study of other processes, and link naturally to the study of trapping models and reinforced random walks. While not explicitly targeted in this proposal, trapping models have recently been used to study the environmental impact of nuclear waste, and RWRE's can naturally be used in this context to model the spread of contamination in a real environment, once the required mathematical background and tools are in place.


The primary focus of the proposed research is the long term behavior of RWRE (random walks in random environments). More precisely, one looks at random walks on thed-dimensional lattice, whose transition probabilities form a random field indexed by the vertices of the lattice. Not only is the RWRE providing a serious mathematical challenge, many of the results proved in this field, especially in the one dimensional case, stand in sharp contrast with the behavior of classical random walk. For example, in dimension 1, subdiffusive behavior and aging phenomena are present, whereas in high dimension one may construct RWRE's with nonzero (averaged) local drift pointing in one direction while the walk drifts away (with positive speed)in the opposite direction. Some of the mathematical challenge emanates from the fact that in the multidimensional case, conditioned on the transition probabilities random field, the RWRE is not reversible. This precludes the use of much of the available theory of homogenization, and requires the development of new techniques, most notably through the use of regeneration times and of renormalization ideas. In spite of rapid progress that was achieved in the last few years by several researchers including Bolthausen, Sznitman, Varadhan, Zerner, and the PI, many fundamental questions remain unanswered. Among these one notes the existence of 0-1 laws, laws of large numbers in full generality, transience and recurrence criteria, the existence (or non-existence) of sub-diffusive behavior for high dimension, and the behavior of RWRE's in mixing (as opposed to i.i.d.)environments. One direction of intensive study will be the extension of existing renormalization techniques, in order to fully resolve the perturbative regime of RWRE.

This project was concerned with several aspects of modern probability theory and its applications. The goal was to develop new tools that would apply in a broad range of probability applications. It focused on various models of random walks (arguably, the stochastic process most studied by mathematicians) and models of random matrices (again, a fundamental concept in mathematics). The following specific point are part of the main new techniques and discoveries resulting from the project.

  1. A good part of modern wireless technology utilizes the theory of random matrices, both in the design of efficient codes and of efficient antenna arrays. Mathematically, this often involves the study of large random matrices where most entries are nonzero and random. However, in certain applications, one needs to address much sparser matrices (often reflecting local spatial interactions between communication cells). In joint work with Levy and Shamai, techniques borrowed from the theory of random Schroedinger operators were extended and applied to this wireless setup, resulting with a method of analysis of such systems.
  2. Certain recursions that are similar to those appearing in the evolution of branching particles play an important role in the study of seemingly unrelated  problems, such as the study of extremes in certain Gaussian fields (called Gaussian free fields) and the study of the time it takes for a random walk to completely cover a graph. This observation motivated an ongoing research effort with the goal of leveraging (old) techniques developed for the branching particles evolution to these more modern problems. This required refining existing methods and combining tools coming from the study of Gaussian fields with analytical considerations related to the above mentioned recursions. This part of the project settled long standing conjectures (including the evaluation of the order of fluctuations of the maximum of certain Gaussian fields) as well as discovered new phenomena concerning phase transitions for the speed of propagation of the ``cloud'' of branching particles. A good part of the work in this direction was done in collaboration with M. Bramson and with J. Ding,  together with PhD student M. Fang and significant contributions from non-US based experts E. Bolthausen and J.-D. Deuschel.
  3. Much effort in the theory  of random matrices has been expanded toward the study of symmetric matrices; those matrices have the property that their spectra are stable to small perturbations. Part of the research effort was spent in developing methods allowing one to handle non-symmetric matrices, and to predict the spectrum of such matrices under small perturbations. This effort has combined tools from several areas of mathematics: complex analysis, operator theory, free probability and concentration inequalities. The end product is a set of tools that allows one to address in a mathematically rigorous way questions that had been accessible so far only by heuristics and physical arguments.  A large part of this part of the research was done in collaboration with A. Guionnet.
  4. Finally, various aspects of random motion in disordered media were considered. As part of an international collaboration involving G. Ben Arous, Y. Hu and S. Olla, the Einstein relation (which relates the response to perturbation of a system at equilibrium to the size of fluctuations there) was demonstrated  for motion on a (random) tree structure, providing one of the few examples where such a relation can be verified for a disordered system. This was also extended to another class of systems possessing no local drift by PhD student X. Guo.
